Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: EXERCISE - Explore Emerging Computing in Science and Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award renews the EXERCISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Salisbury University, Maryland. The intellectual focus of the site is research on emerging paradigms in parallel computing. The Principal Investigator, together with mentors, will supervise a 10-week REU program that gives a diverse cohort of students a taste of computational thinking in the domain of parallel computing and also an understanding of the graduate school experience. The projects cover a breadth of areas in parallel computing and the students will gain experience in all aspects of research. The emphasis on parallel computing is important particularly at a time when multicore and multiprocessor architectures are becoming ubiquitous and more and more applications are utilizing parallelism. To ensure diversity, students will be selected from within Salisbury University as well as from regional community colleges, University of Maryland Eastern Shore and other Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

Because of the ubiquity of multicore and multiprocessor architectures, parallel computing has become an important area of research in computing science. However, parallel computing brings with it several challenges. There are fundamental difficulties in program semantics related to process interleaving: a parallel program can yield inconsistent answers, or even crash, due to unpredictable interactions between simultaneous tasks. Secondly, communication, memory access, and I/O overhead may result in run-time delays. Finally, it is difficult to ensure that programs consume resources in a manner that simultaneously achieves efficiency and meets performance goals. Based on the above challenges, the REU Site will focus on four aspects of parallel computing, namely, algorithms, software, architecture and applications. Students will work with faculty mentors in completing cutting-edge research projects to tackle data and compute intensive applications that emphasize the above four aspects. By the end of program, students will acquire valuable skills, gain a broader and deeper understanding of research, and develop greater confidence in their abilities. In particular, they will be exposed to emerging paradigms in parallel computing such as MapReduce and GPU computing, and will have opportunities to explore concurrent software and multiprocessor architectures, and design efficient parallel algorithms, and to tackle data and compute intensive problems in computer and social networks, image and signal processing, and geographic information systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU site: "EXERCISE - Explore Emerging Computing in Science and Engineering" (Feb 2015 - Jan 2019) has provided valuable research experiences in high performance computing (HPC) to a total of thirty undergraduate students and helped them build confidence in research and develop problem-solving skills. During the summer research program, students applied emerging parallel computing models such as GPU computing with NVIDIA CUDA (a local parallel processing system) and MapReduce computing on clusters (a distributed parallel processing system) to tackle data and compute-intensive problems in computer networks and security, image and signal processing, and geographic information system.

The REU site placed recruiting efforts on woman and underrepresented minorities, particularly students from historically black college and universities (HBCUs) and primarily undergraduate institutions (PUIs) with limited research resources and opportunities. The application data reveals that the application pool consists of over 29% females, 21% African Americans, 9% Hispanic/Latinos, and 1% Native Americans/American Indians. The total number of applicants of last three years is 160 with each year over 50 applicants, where 70% of applicants are from PUIs with limited research resources and 51% are belong to underrepresented minority groups. The REU student participants were 20% (6/30) females, 10% (3/30) African Americans, 7% (2/30) Hispanic/Latinos, and 3% (1/30) Native Americans/American Indians. Notably, there were 73% (22/30) REU participants from outside of the REU site home school and 73% (22/30) from PUIs and community colleges including Borough Manhattan Community College, Santa Rosa Junior College, Berry College, Wheaton College, Swarthmore College, Smith College, Randolph-Macon College, Hampden-Sydney College, Elon University, Xavier University, and University of Puerto Rico at Rio Piedras.

The REU project assessment showed that that the overall experiences for the REU participants were rewarding. Students indicated that the REU program provided a rich learning environment and met or exceeded their expectations. Particularly, the students' experiences of the summer research, field trips, and the REU program in general were very positive. Students were pleased with the teamwork, living on campus, frequent progress reports and interaction with faculty members. The results that used both the matched pairs' t-test for mean difference and the Wilcoxon Signed-Rank test for median difference obtained from the post-survey compared to the pre-survey suggested that the students had significant gain in their perceived knowledge about research after the REU experience! During the exit program interviews with an independent project evaluator, the REU students commented: "The most rewarding experience for me was the ability to work with my faculty mentor on a one-on-one fashion, which I had never been able to do before...This has given me an idea of what it would be like to attend graduate school and be part of a small research team...The collaborative environment contributed to making the research experience much more rewarding...I enjoyed being able to discuss with my peers about our different projects...This is also the first time where I've felt that an extracurricular project that I've undertaken has actually succeeded, and I attribute it to the guidance and suggestions provided by my mentor...Very satisfied with the experience...Enjoyed the trip to NASA...Liked everything...All good...Well run! "

The REU project results were well disseminated. All REU students presented their summer projects at the SU's Henson Summer Research Program Symposium. Some of them have been selected to present their research projects at IEEE/ACM International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis (Supercomputing), SPIE Scientific Sensing and Imaging Conference, SPIE Conference on Computational Imaging, Anniversary National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR), National Workshop for REU Research in Networking and Systems, Emerging Researchers National Conference in STEM, Maryland STEM Festival, and SU Annual Student Research Conference. The REU site has generated five publications in which REU students were the leading authors from the project summer research program. The PI and faculty mentors were invited to give talks in SIAM Conference on Computational Science and Engineering and the SU annual Research Day and Innovation Showcase. The PI was also invited as a panelist for the session "Mixing Effective Research and REU Students" in the 2016 NSF CISE REU PI meeting.

The REU EXERCISE project has broader impacts on multiple communities including encouraging undergraduate students to pursue graduate studies and professional careers in computing; providing valuable education and research resources for PUIs and HBCUs with limited computing research facilities; sparking local high school students' interests in science and engineering careers and having positive influence on regional workforce development; successfully promoting "parallel thinking," an important computational thinking skill, among current generation students and attracting more students to future careers in STEM areas.

The project website is available on http://faculty.salisbury.edu/~ealu/REU/REU.html.
